seo.meta_title: Sugarloaf Mountain Trail Guide | 2 Routes, Maps & Conditions
seo.meta_description: Plan your Sugarloaf Mountain hike with live conditions, 2 trail maps & parking info. NH 4000-Footer at 4,237 ft.

schema_place.name: Sugarloaf Mountain
schema_place.description: Sugarloaf Mountain is a 4,237 foot peak in Maine offering hiking trails with scenic views.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Sugarloaf Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Sugarloaf Mountain take 5-7 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 10.4 miles with Hard difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Sugarloaf Mountain hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Sugarloaf Mountain is rated Hard. At 4,237 feet, expect challenging terrain above treeline with potential for rapid weather changes. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Sugarloaf Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Sugarloaf Mountain. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Sugarloaf Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Appalachian Trail (from Caribou Valley Rd), offering AT approach passing Sugarloaf summit spur..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Sugarloaf Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Sugarloaf Mountain is late May through October. Summer and fall offer the best conditions, though expect crowds on weekends. Winter hiking requires specialized gear and experience.

page_content.description:
At 4,237 feet, Sugarloaf Mountain ranks among New Hampshire's celebrated 4000-Footers—a collection of 48 peaks that challenge and inspire hikers throughout the Northeast. This hard summit offers a quintessential White Mountain experience.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Appalachian Trail (from Caribou Valley Rd)**, covers 10.4 miles and is rated Hard. AT approach passing Sugarloaf summit spur.

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** Spaulding Mountain lies just 1.2 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.conditions: Muddy trails, snow above 3000ft until May
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.conditions: Peak foliage late Sept, early snow possible in October
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.conditions: Full winter conditions, extreme cold and wind above treeline
winter.tips: Winter hiking requires specialized skills and gear. Never hike alone. Check avalanche conditions for steeper terrain.

current_hazards: ⚠️ ALPINE ZONE: Weather changes rapidly. Turn back if conditions deteriorate.
Winter conditions in effect - full mountaineering gear required
Hypothermia risk - temperatures 20-40°F colder at summit
Trail markers may be buried under snow
